 This is just to show the board layout. There is no set layout, or design,=
 it's just where ever the stuff fits. I tend to put the sweep in the upper =
left corner of the board as I'm workign on it, although in the pix it looks=
 like in the lower right corner. The tuner is oriented on as different side=
 than on #31. I start by locating the tuner, whether it's home made, or one=
 of these modules, then I place the power terminal. Then place the chip soc=
kets. Then I start with wiring the power to each chip, and proceed from the=
re. I use orange for minus 12 volts, red for plus 12, and plus 8 volts, and=
 green for all grounds. It's just to help in troubelshooting if needed. I u=
se a ground bus around the under side of the board edge.  I use #24 scrap t=
elephone wire just because it free.  I install phone and network lines. 
 
=
 You have to use shielded wire for the speaker lines, or there's too much f=
eedback to the mic circuits by induction. 
 
 These tuner modules are from =
old scraped boxes, # 3, and #11. The noise pick up from the white noise cir=
cuit was so bad that the tuner wouldn't work, the RF signals being complete=
ly drowned out by white noise, which has been a major problem with the boxe=
s since day one, and why I find the random mode so easy to abandon. These t=
uner modules work just fine without the white noise, and the systems work v=
ery well in linear mode.
 
 The "Range" and "Center" controls alow the tuni=
ng to be narrowed to a specific area in the AM band, such as the supposed R=
audive frequency of 1485 khz. It's an experimental mode that I was putting =
in the boxes, but never had time to play with.  The "Range" can be turned a=
ll the way down, and "Center" used as manual tuning. 
 
 I was going to apo=
logize for getting harsh last Friday, but I make the boxes, I understand ho=
w it works, and how to make it work, yet some with no knowledge of technolo=
gy, or the boxes, think they can presume to tell me how it really works, to=
 limit it to a "chosen" few, I think--I get pissed. Now I don't know how th=
e spirits actually form their voices, but I do know that just about anythin=
g that provides a raw audio that they can use to make a voice will be used,=
 and it doesn't matter if the sound is random, or linear.
